channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [MAHOUT-939] ASF Email Classification Examples don't always produce good results
item.description: The classification examples for the ASF email don't work all that well currently in terms of quality when it comes to more than a few labels. Also, need to determine how much memory is required for vectors of cardinality size 100K.
item.summary: ASF Email Classification Examples don't always produce good results

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Details please.

  1. Data set and provenance
  2. Arguments
  3. Number of iterations
  4. Evaluation at each snapshot of SGD model - really illuminating
It's the asf-email-examples.sh in examples/bin and the data set is the ASF email archive.
Here's a start on this. Added some more construction options to the AdaptiveLogisticRegression class. Still testing what values to use in TrainASFEmail, but thought I would put this up for now.
Adds in some CLI options
Add quote stripping, amongst other changes. Results are good for simple two class version, still trying on bigger number of labels.
Committed some progress on this. I marked the classification examples as experimental for now and am going to change the fix version to be 0.7 so that we can move towards the release.

Integrated in Mahout-Quality #1295 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/Mahout-Quality/1295/)
MAHOUT-939: Add in ability to alter pool size and thread count, mark ASF email classification examples as experimental

gsingers : http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/?root=Apache-SVN&view=rev&rev=1228875
Files :

  • /mahout/trunk/core/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/classifier/sgd/AdaptiveLogisticRegression.java
  • /mahout/trunk/core/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/common/AbstractJob.java
  • /mahout/trunk/examples/bin/asf-email-examples.sh
  • /mahout/trunk/examples/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/classifier/sgd/TrainASFEmail.java
  • /mahout/trunk/integration/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/text/SequenceFilesFromMailArchives.java
  • /mahout/trunk/integration/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/utils/email/MailOptions.java
  • /mahout/trunk/integration/src/main/java/org/apache/mahout/utils/email/MailProcessor.java
  • /mahout/trunk/integration/src/test/java/org/apache/mahout/utils/email/MailProcessorTest.java

SGD now does:

  • 88% with just the subject,
  • 98% with just the body, with and without quoted text
  • 2% with body with quoted text
  • 3% with subject and body without quoted text
  • 2% with subject and body and quoted text

The subject-only test is the only believable output. One guess is that this gives many fewer terms. Based on that guess, would hashing vectorization with a small dimension give better results?
On what dataset? It works fine w/ just commons and cocoon, but if you add in more labels, it doesn't seem to do so hot, AFAICT.

This patch includes the MAHOUT-941 code for stripping quoted text, and also an option for rejecting messages which contain specific lines. The rejecter allows you to identify and remove "spam" messages.

For the Apache mails, we can add a job props file that lists patterns to remove, like build notifications.

Are these results with held-out data? Or are they what is reported by the cross fold learners?

The cross fold stuff has a known issue when there is item to item correlation (as with quoted text or other conversational structure). This amounts to a target leak that causes the ALR to stop learning too early and to kill regularization.

I think that the long-term solution is to give the ALR training and test sets and not worry about the cross validation. Cross validation helps with small data sets and hurts with large ones which seems a contradiction with our basic mission. Also, going with this option would radically decrease the memory required.

I did my testing on the Apache commons/cocoon dataset. rejectionPercent 20, mapreduce splits. The SGD option. Key sequence 3-3-2 for classification, sgd, 2 labels.

39903 test files
=======================================================
Summary
-------------------------------------------------------
Correctly Classified Instances : 1198 3.0023%
Incorrectly Classified Instances : 38705 96.9977%
Total Classified Instances : 39903

=======================================================
Confusion Matrix
-------------------------------------------------------
a b <--Classified as
861 19244 | 20105 a = commons_apache_org
19461 337 | 19798 b = cocoon_apache_org

Avg. Log-likelihood: -2.17279868506715 25%-ile: -2.572078768074387 75%-ile: -1.8312213190676514

Update to trunk.

This patch lets you reject mail messages if they match a one-line pattern in the headers. Intended for stripping out spam leaker mails like build messages.
Another oddity: using the full apache commons v.s. cocoon database of tens of thousands of emails, Bayesian classification ends up with 300 emails. This is with the default script.

Are these results with held-out data? Or are they what is reported by the cross fold learners?

Here are the steps we do currently:

  1. Convert mail archives to sequence files
  2. Encode the text using seq2encoded: 
    $MAHOUT seq2encoded --input $MAIL_OUT --output $SEQ2SP --analyzerName org.apache.mahout.text.MailArchivesClusteringAnalyzer --cardinality 100000
  3. Do some minor reworking of the vectors to get decent labels
  4. Split the vectors into a train and test set, randomizing as we go thanks to MAHOUT-904 
    $MAHOUT split --input $SEQ2SPLABEL --mapRedOutputDir $MAPREDOUT  --randomSelectionPct 20 --overwrite --sequenceFiles --method mapreduce
  5. Run the training
  6. Run the test

All of this is in examples/bin/asf-email-examples.sh

The code for TrainASFModel more or less mirrors what is in the 20NewsGroup by using ALR. I even refactored the two a bit to share some common code. Hopefully I didn't mess things up there despite the tests passing and the results looking reasonable.

This patches examples/bin/asf-email-examples.sh so that bayesian classification works. The split output directory MapRedDir thing was set wrong.

I just ran through reccos, classification, and the kmeans clusterer. Dirichlet and minhash take forever, so haven't tested those yet.
In answer to the previous comment: I only ran example/bin/asf-email-examples.sh. I did not copy out any scripting or code.
asf_samples_list.txt is a complete listing of the ASF sample email corpus I used for these tests. Does it match your copy?

Fixed this, the new naivebayes classifier shows awesome results with asf mail archives.

encoding takes 200 seconds
train 222s
test 117s
12/06/04 18:18:49 INFO test.TestNaiveBayesDriver: Complementary Results: =======================================================

-------------------------------------------------------

Incorrectly Classified Instances : 1512 2.1658%
Total Classified Instances : 69814
=======================================================
Confusion Matrix
-------------------------------------------------------
a b <--Classified as
27633 796 | 28429 a = commons.apache.org
716 40669 | 41385 b = cocoon.apache.org

Integrated in Mahout-Quality #1530 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/Mahout-Quality/1530/)
MAHOUT-939 Remove warnings from the asf example script (Revision 1346373)

Result = SUCCESS
robinanil : http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/?root=Apache-SVN&view=rev&rev=1346373

I think Robin was just waiting to try this on a bigger set of data, so assigning to him

I dont think this is a release blocker. Please go ahead without this.

I will try to see if I can fix the ngram issue. But given the last few hours I have in berlin, I have less confidence that I will be to find it and fix it. I will be off the next few days in travelling. So Please if I cant fix the ngram issue, can someone take over it ?
FYI. There were 123 classes
